clinical_study.brief_title: Clinical Study to Evaluate CryoBalloon™ Full Ablation System for Ablation of Human Esophageal Epithelium
clinical_study.official_title: Clinical Study to Evaluate the CryoBalloon™ Full Ablation System for Ablation of Human Esophageal Epithelium

brief_summary.textblock: This study will evaluate the CryoBalloon™ Full Ablation System for the ablation of human esophageal epithelium in patients scheduled to undergo esophagectomy for reasons unrelated to the objective of the study

detailed_description.textblock: The primary outcomes for the study are the safety and treatment effect of the CryoBalloon™ Ablation System. An Esophagectomy will be performed as scheduled following the ablation procedure; histopathological analysis of surgically-resected specimens will be performed.

primary_outcome.measure: Safety of the CryoBalloon™ Ablation System by incidence of serious, device-related adverse events
primary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, an average of 2 weeks

primary_outcome.measure: Treatment effect of the CryoBalloon™ Ablation System will be evaluated by depth and uniformity of ablation effect in the esophagus.
primary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, an average of 2 weeks

secondary_outcome.measure: Device Performance: ease of deployment and procedure time both pre and post procedure
secondary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, an average of 2 weeks

arm_group.description: To evaluate CryoBalloon™ Full Ablation System for the ablation of human esophageal epithelium in patients scheduled to undergo esophagectomy.

intervention.description: Tissue Ablation using CryoBalloon™ Full Ablation System

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Minimum of one 3cm area of non-ulcerated columnar-lined esophagus or squamous-lined tissue suitable for ablation
- Older than 18 years of age
- Requires a clinically necessary esophagectomy for esophageal cancer or other indications.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patient has esophageal narrowing limiting access to the intended sites of ablation
